statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Kevin Garnett scored 20 points and the Minnesota Timberwolves finally put together a three-game winning
streak, overcoming a strong performance by Gary Payton to beat Seattle 96-91 Wednesday night.
article.headline: Wolves on first three-game roll of season
article.linkText: Garnett helps T-Wolves finally win three straight
article.story:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- The Minnesota Timberwolves finally won three in a row. But they'd rather think about getting a fourth. Kevin Garnett scored 20 points and the Timberwolves won three straight for the first time in 10 tries, overcoming a strong performance by Gary Payton to beat Seattle 96-91 Wednesday night. "I had to remind everybody on the way walking in when we won, 'That's three in a row,''' Wolves guard Troy Hudson said. "Everybody was like, 'Oh, it is.' So I think that was the key, we didn't think about it, we just wanted to go out and play.'' Garnett also was happy to get finally get the elusive third win, but he wasn't impressed by it. "I didn't see what the big fuss was about,'' Garnett said. "Three in a row. It'd be nice if we can put another three on top of this one.'' The last time Minnesota, which has won seven of its last nine, won three straight games was last April. "I've been a part of bigger streaks,'' Garnett said. "But it's a great start. Let's try to extend it a little bit, keep the focus game to game.'' Garnett's last basket came with 25.4 seconds left on a turnaround jumper to give Minnesota a 92-89 lead. Rashard Lewis made a layup to pull Seattle within a point with 12.5 seconds to go, and Seattle sent Hudson to the free throw line. Hudson, who came off the bench for the second time since returning from an ankle injury, hit both free throws and Lewis airballed a 3-pointer on Seattle's ensuing possession. "We tried to get a pick on (Anthony) Peeler and try to get Brent (Barry) on the fade,'' Lewis said of his desperation heave. "But they switched and K.G. denied Brent and Peeler was in my face. There was nothing I could do.'' Hudson ended up with ball and hit two more foul shots to ice the win. Rasho Nesterovic scored 18 points for the Wolves while Joe Smith, Wally Szczerbiak and Hudson each added 16. Payton led Seattle with 20 points and 13 assists and went 10-for-13 from the floor. Desmond Mason added 14 points. Payton almost singlehandedly kept Seattle in the game against the sluggish Wolves. When he wasn't swishing buckets, he was tiring out Minnesota's defenders, zipping around the court without the ball. But the Wolves clamped down on him during the final minutes and forced Seattle's other players to shoot. "I shot the ball well today and got everybody involved,'' Payton said. "They didn't want me to do what I had to do to beat them. They doubled and switched to make it tough for me to see and pass.'' Payton's 18-footer with 3:38 to play pulled the Sonics to 88-87. Garnett and Kenny Anderson traded baskets and Smith was called for charging on Minnesota's next possession. The Sonics caught a break when Lewis rebounded Anderson's miss to give Seattle a new shot clock. But Barry missed a 3-pointer and Gill came down with the rebound to set up Garnett's turnaround. "I just didn't take the extra half-second and I probably could have,'' Barry said. "Some go in and some don't.'' Smith was a bright spot for the Wolves, who shot 42-for-80 from the floor. Smith, the only Timberwolves player to shoot a free throw through three quarters, went 4-for-6 and showed nice hustle. In the third quarter, Smith followed an airball by blocking a shot in transition and running the floor for a layup. He brought the crowd to its feet with a flying, two-handed jam to give the Wolves a 64-53 lead with 6:53 to go in the third quarter. Seattle trailed by as many as 15 points in the first half. The Wolves opened the game hitting nine of their first 10 shots en route to 39 first quarter points, their highest-scoring quarter this season. But the Sonics scored eight unanswered to pull to 39-32 early in the second. Payton went 7-of-8 in the first half for 14 points.

Game notes
Gill scored the 12,000th point of his career on his first shot of the game. ... The Wolves have won eight straight against the Sonics at Target Center. ... Minnesota shot 17-for-22 in the first quarter, including 3-for-4 from 3-point range. ... Sonics F Vladimir Radmanovic returned to the lineup after missing Seattle's previous three games with a sprained ankle.
